children.subject: I personally found 61A completely useless for 61B (and in general), but mostly because I knew Java syntax and the basics of 61B beforehand. I'd suggest studying for 61B rather than 61A if you want to study something over the summer, and if you fail to understand something that you think was discussed in 61A already, then go back to 61A for that particular subtopic.

The last third of 61A is probably the least helpful part of 61A for 61B. If you understand Python basics, class attributes vs. instance attributes, and frames/environment diagrams, you should be okay. I’d recommend reviewing some Java (like watch last semester’s first few videos) rather than reviewing Python to prepare.

I agree w/ the previous 2 posts and I wouldn't suggest retaking 61A. If you have some time you'd like to dedicate to brushing up on specific topics, I would recommend reviewing OOP, linked lists, trees, iterators, and orders of growth.

history.content: I took 61A in fall semester and did pretty well until the last third of the class when I started having some health issues. The content totally passed me by but I was still able to pass the class. How will this affect me when taking 61B (especially after a semester of no CS)? I've been toying with retaking 61A to actually learn the material, but I know it wouldn't change my grade or anything, I would only be doing it to become more confident in the course content. Should I just try and learn the content I missed on my own in preparation for 61B? I want to take it this summer but I'm afraid the missing knowledge from 61A will affect my performance. How much is 61B dependent on 61A? Thank you!
history.subject: How much is 61B dependent on 61A?
